basics.name: Benjamin (Ben) Glasner, Ph.D.
basics.label: Economist
basics.summary: Economist at the Economic Innovation Group (EIG). Former Postdoctoral Research Scientist with Columbia University’s Center on Poverty and Social Policy. Ph.D. and M.Sc. in Public Policy & Management (University of Washington); B.A. in Economics (Vassar College).

work.name: Economic Innovation Group
work.summary: Conducts economic research and public-facing analysis on U.S. labor markets and related policy issues, including economic writing, data visualization, and stakeholder outreach.

work.name: Center on Poverty and Social Policy, Columbia University
work.summary: Conducted analyses of major U.S. social policies and reforms, including studies related to the intergenerational transmission of poverty.
highlights: Work with CPSP investigators (per CV): Irwin Garfinkel, Jane Waldfogel, and Christopher Wimer

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: Served as the primary analyst for equity- and inclusion-related feedback, coordinating and analyzing focus groups and surveys with faculty, staff, students, alumni, and donors.

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: Primary instructor for a course section, developing and delivering material for students with diverse skill levels.

work.name: World Bank Group (via University of Washington)
work.summary: Performed expenditure analysis using survey data, including work on missingness and seasonality; contributed to a working paper.
highlights: Survey data methods and expenditure analysis

volunteer.organization: Seattle Mayor's Office & Advisory Team for Senator Mark Warner
volunteer.summary: Provided strategic advice on local labor markets, independent contracting, and unemployment insurance.

volunteer.organization: Utah Legislative Session Report on SB 233
volunteer.summary: Co-developed an executive summary outlining policy options intended to increase legal clarity and bolster benefits for independent contractors.

volunteer.organization: Washington State Employment Security Department & World Bank
volunteer.summary: Contributed to development of new data tools and methods for analysis of incomplete survey data across developing economies.

education.institution: Evans School of Public Policy and Governance, University of Washington
courses: Dissertation: The Impact of Public Policy on Nonstandard Work Arrangements
Undergraduate thesis: The Chinese Hukou System: Structural Change and Political Reform

awards.title: Pi Alpha Alpha Doctoral Manuscript Award
awards.summary: Recognizes an outstanding doctoral student paper (per CV).

awards.title: NASPAA Staats Emerging Scholar
awards.summary: Awarded to up to three Ph.D. candidates (per CV).

awards.title: Agnes Reynolds Jackson Prize
awards.summary: Prize recognizing excellence in academic research and writing (per CV).

publications.name: The Minimum Wage, Self-Employment, and the Online Gig Economy
publications.summary: Estimates the effect of minimum wage increases on work not covered by minimum wage laws; finds heterogeneous effects across traditional self-employment and online gig economy activity.

publications.name: No Evidence the Child Tax Credit Expansion Has Affected the Well-being and Mental Health of Parents
publications.summary: Analysis of survey-based evidence on parental well-being and mental health in the context of the 2021 expanded Child Tax Credit.

publications.name: Effects of the expanded Child Tax Credit on employment outcomes
publications.summary: Estimates employment impacts of the expanded Child Tax Credit using real-world data from 2021.

publications.name: The Effectiveness of the Food Stamp Program at Reducing Racial Differences in the Intergenerational Persistence of Poverty
publications.publisher: Center on Poverty & Social Policy / Washington Center for Equitable Growth (Working Paper)
publications.summary: Investigates how Food Stamp Program expansions affected intergenerational poverty and racial disparities.

publications.name: Liquid Assets, Financial Shocks, and Entrances into Material Hardship
publications.summary: Examines how liquid assets buffer households against financial shocks and transitions into material hardship.

publications.name: Effects of Noncompete Agreement Reforms on Business Formation
publications.summary: Studies the relationship between noncompete agreement reforms and business formation.

publications.name: The American Worker: Toward a New Consensus
publications.summary: A policy and research synthesis on the state of work in the U.S. and a proposed agenda for a new consensus.

publications.name: The Great “Transfer”-mation: How American communities became reliant on income from government
publications.summary: Documents the rise of transfer income across U.S. communities and discusses implications for regional political economy.

publications.name: The Impact of Opportunity Zones on Housing Supply
publications.summary: Provides quantitative evidence on the effect of Opportunity Zones on housing supply using HUD/USPS address data.

projects.name: The Great “Transfer”-mation (code repository)
projects.summary: Repository with data and code supporting EIG’s report on the rise of transfer income across U.S. communities.

projects.name: The Impact of Opportunity Zones on Housing Supply (code repository)
projects.summary: Repository with methods and documentation supporting EIG’s working paper estimating OZ effects on housing supply.

projects.name: Policy, News, and Media
projects.summary: Selected media appearances and coverage (per CV), including CBS MoneyWatch and mentions in outlets such as the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, Washington Post, Bloomberg, CBS News, Yahoo Finance, and MarketWatch.
